channel.title: Commands and Switches?

item.title: Commands and Switches?
item.dc:creator: @Phobia.Bosco Phobia.Bosco
item.description:
@Phobia.Bosco wrote:

[quote=“Onix, post:2, topic:444572”]I actually have no idea, I think it depends on the programmer who makes the base for the source, because once they make it, the people who use it for their servers don’t change the basic layout like this.

Just use anything that works for you.[/quote]

Well, actually in my base, for some reason, no matter what I tried the commands needed owner status, even when I deleted all of the if(c.playerRights == ) part… I couldn’t figure it out, but after translating the commands into switches, they all worked, and for me I liked it a little better.

But, If for whatever reason, switches makes the source unstable or use too many resources, I would go back to if statements.

Thanks,

phobia.bosco

Read full topic

item.title: Commands and Switches?
item.dc:creator: @Onix Onix
item.description:
@Onix wrote:

I actually have no idea, I think it depends on the programmer who makes the base for the source, because once they make it, the people who use it for their servers don’t change the basic layout like this.

Just use anything that works for you.

item.title: Commands and Switches?
item.dc:creator: @Phobia.Bosco Phobia.Bosco
item.description:
@Phobia.Bosco wrote:

Hey guys, so I’m new here, but I just have a simple question that hopefully can be answered to me.

(this is first time coding a RSPS no hate )

When looking at the commands.java (PI based) I noticed all the If statements. Now your most likely thinking, WOW BATMAN! But I was wondering, why can’t you use switches, or rather why don’t they, when most of the commands are centered around whether or not the player has a certain player rights or donor etc.

For example:

if(command.startsWith("Testing")){ switch (c.playerRights){ case 0: // do stuff break; case 1: //do stuff break;

I didn’t finish because you guys most likely knew what I was talking about before seeing the example. Please explain why if are > switch?

NOTE: I tested this for a few commands and liked the results

Please don’t say just for cleaning source with only that as the reasoning.

Thanks,

phobia.bosco

Read full topic
